name: Gather Your Records
section_name: Gather and safeguard your own important personal records. Vault
summary: Preserving your own personal records gets you off to a good start and helps you protect your valuable information.

choices.name: Gather your own important records.

hidden.content: • Gather your important personal documents.
• * Proficient: Make a list of the important personal documents you should have, and then collect and store them safely.

content.text:
1. Locate and safely store your birth certificate, religious records, marriage certificate, legal documents, etc.
  2. If you are missing any important records, arrange to get replacements of them.

resources.description: Here are some helpful ideas for gathering your own family history records.

links.text: FS—Gather Family Information
Gathering Home Sources—3:38 - 2020

resources.description: Keep a journal to capture events in your life and personal reflections.See Choice C in Project 2: Memories, Goal 9 for details.

links.text: Choice C

choices.name: Gather photos and documents you have of your ancestors.

hidden.content:
• Gather family history documents and photos in your possession and learn more about them.
  • See timing 10:25 of the Inherited Records video in Step 4 for ideas on what to treasure, set aside, or discard.

• Gather Heirlooms and Documents
  • Sort
  • Keep or toss
  • Preserve and protect
  • What to Do with Paper
  • Dealing with Photos

• Sort
  • Store
  • Share

• * Good: Make a catalog of the family history photos and documents you have.
  • * Proficient: Sort your photos and documents using the ideas in the Inherited Records video. Then list three ways you could use these items (see the BYU video).

content.text:
1. Record what you know from records and sources easily available.

    ☆ BYU—Creating a Family Archive (19:00) - 2014   
    • Gather Heirlooms and Documents
    • Sort
    • Keep or toss
    • Preserve and protect
    • What to Do with Paper
    • Dealing with Photos




  2. Learn how to find the treasures in family records that are in your possession.

    ☆ BYU—Inherited Records? Now What? —43:08 - 2016  
    • Sort
    • Store
    • Share




  3. Watch these videos to learn about the importance of documenting stories and photographs.

    ☆ AAC—Document Your Family Stories—9:55 (acct. req.)
    ☆ AAC—Document Your Family Treasures and Photographs—11:26 (acct. req.)

  4. Here are five reasons for documenting your family's story.

    ☆ 5 Reasons Why You Should Document Your Family’s Story - 2017

  5. Learn more about family records and how you can use them. Examples include journals, diaries, letters, photographs, and family bibles.

    ☆ BYU—Family Records—24:23
    ☆ FS—U.S. Bible Records

  6. Analyzing: Watch this video for guidelines on deciding whether objects are heirlooms, documentation, or junk.

    ☆ RT—Heirloom, Documentation or Junk: What to Keep or Toss —47:57
    ☆ Family Heirlooms

  7. Clues: Learn how to find research clues in your family mementos.

    ☆ How To Find Research Clues in your Family Mementos

  8. Learn about how to discover the history of your home.

    ☆ A Guide to Researching the History of a House - 2020

  9. Learn how baby books can provide provide valuable family history clues.

    ☆ FE—Using Baby Books as a Genealogy Tool

choices.name: Make scans or paper copies of each document or photo to serve as backups.

hidden.content:
• Learning Center, Ancestry Wiki
  • Silver hilade degradation
  • Resolution DPI and PPI
  • Save as ...
  • RGB and CMYK
  • Backup

• Preserve old artifacts
  • Digitize and preserve old bibles
  • Where to get archival materials
  • Acid-free paper
  • How to preserve old photographs
  • Folders and notebooks
  • Preserving old newspapers
  • How to preserve old newspapers
  • Materials for preservation
  • Can you write on the back of photos?
• * Proficient: Scan all important family history documents and photos in your possession.

content.text:
1. If you don't have access to a scanner, visit a library or family history center to use one, or use a digital camera to make digital copies. For tips on scanning, see Goal 5.
  2. Back up digital copies to external devices (thumb drive, etc.) or to the Internet.

resources.description: Google Photos: Use Google Photos to back up and store your family history photos.

links.text: MH—Google Photos: one photo app to rule them all—88:00

resources.description: Scanning: Learn basic scanning skills in this video.

links.text: Scanning and Beyond—41:52 - 2020

resources.description: Backups/Archival: Read these tips on backing up your smartphone photos.

links.text: AC—Backing Up Smartphone Photos - 2015

resources.description: Learn about different formats for your digital files.

links.text: Digitizing Family Photos and Records: What's the Best Format to Use?

resources.description: Learn how to archive your family history memories.

links.text: GTV: How to Archive Your Family History Documents, Photos, & Artifacts—34:58 - 2019

resources.description: Learn about backing up your files from genealogy websites.

links.text: Why You Should Download Your Files From Ancestry and Every Other Website - 2017

resources.description: Here are some tips for managing your scans and digital photographs.

links.text: FS—Managing Scanned and Digital Photos—23:46 - 2021

choices.name: Protect and preserve your original documents and backups.

hidden.content:
• Take care of and preserve original photos and documents.
  • In storage areas, avoid high temperatures, humidity, and direct light.
  • Identify and record information in photos, such as people and events.
  • Use best practices for deciding on what type of photography or filming to do.

• Paper vs. electronics
  • Paper as an information storage medium
  • Why are we concerned with paper?
  • What is paper?
  • How long does paper last?
  • Causes of deterioration and loss
  • Tips
  • Conservation measures
  • Storage
• * Proficient: Make a list of the important personal documents you should have, and then collect and store them safely.

content.text:
1. Store original documents and backups in separate, secure locations.
  2. Choose a safe, dry place for physical copies.
  3. Watch this video to learn about the importance of preserving your family photos and memories.


  4. Learn about passing your family history assets on to the next generation.

    ☆ FTM—How to Pass On Research: What to Include in Your “Genealogy Will”

resources.description: Tips: Explore the CollectionCareTips site for ideas on preserving important photos and documents.

links.text: CollectionCareTips site

resources.description: Visit the Library of Congress site for ideas on preserving many types of archives.

links.text: Library of Congress site

resources.description: Learn about digital preservation of your family history records.

links.text: Preserving Your Family History Records Digitally - 2010

resources.description: For more ideas on preserving documents and photos, read these articles.

links.text: FS—Simple Steps to Preserve Your Precious Family Memories
Preserving Your Photographs - 1994

resources.description: Letters/Books: Here are some tips for preserving old family letters and books.

links.text: MH—Preserving Old Family Letters - 2019
FS: How to Preserve and Restore Family Records and Books

resources.description: Learn how to preserve various paper documents.

links.text: BYU—Basic Paper Document Preservation—56:44 - 2020

resources.description: Newspapers: Learn how to preserve old newspaper clippings.

links.text: MH—5 Easy Steps to Preserving Newspaper Clippings - 2019

resources.description: Heirlooms: Learn how to preserve a variety of family mementos.

links.text: GT—A Short Primer on Preserving Your Heirlooms - 2012

choices.name: (Optional) Restore damaged photographs when possible.

hidden.content:
• Electronic restoration - scanning and Photoshop, etc.
  • Chemical restoration - bleaching and dyeing (professional skills needed)
  • Physical restoration - expensive
  • Copying restoration - changing a duplicate
  • Airbrush restoration - using airbrush technology for improving a copy

content.text:
1. Learn about restoring photographs in this article.

    ☆ GC—Restoring Damaged Photographs

  2. Here are some tips on making bad family photos better.

    ☆ AC—5 Easy Ways to Fix Bad Family Photos - 2016
    ☆ How To Fix Bad Family Photos

  3. Get help restoring or dating your photographs from members of the RootsChat forum.

choices.name: Use Google Photos to store and organize digital photos.

content.text:
1. Learn how to get started with Google Photos.

    ☆ FS: What Is Google Photos? - 2019
    ☆ FS: Getting Started with Google Photos - 2022

  2. Learn more about using Google Photos in these articles.

    ☆ FS: Google Photos—A Genealogist's Dream? - 2019
    ☆ FS: Google Photos and Genealogy, A Perfect Picture - 2018

  3. Learn how to use Google Photos to help in your genealogy research.

    ☆ FS: A Guide to Using Google Photos for Genealogy - 2018
    ☆ AF: How to Use Google Images to Further Your Genealogy Research - 2019

name: Gather Records from Others
section_name: Gather photos and documents of ancestors from others, and organize them.
summary: This helps you learn about your ancestors' lives in a personal way.

choices.name: Contact living relatives or others who might have photos or documents for you to add.

hidden.content: • Find living relatives, and find out what they know or who they think would be best to talk to. Older relatives may have more first-hand memories about documents and photos.

• * Good: Contact a living relative who has additional family history items to share, and then work out an arrangement to share the items.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for two to five living relatives.

content.text:
In some cases, these people may have already added photos and documents to Memories.

  1. Click a photo for an ancestor in your tree. In FamilySearch Memories you can click the Contributed by link to show the email address of the contributor (if available). In Ancestry, MyHeritage, and Findmypast, the contributor information appears next to the photo, for other trees you are viewing.
  2. Compile a contact list from contributors discovered in the previous step.
  3. Read the articles for ideas on reaching out to others for photos and documents, and then make the contacts.

    ☆ FS—How to Gather Family Information
    ☆ LDS—Net Results - 2004

  4. Offer to send physical copies of photos or documents to relatives if they would like them.

hidden.content:
• Label photos with as many details as you know (age, name, date it was taken, location, etc.).
  • When physically labeling the photo, use the correct type of writing utensil to preserve the photo as much as possible.
  • Journals, letters, and diaries are some of the most valuable family records, but photos and documents are just as useful.
  • You can often unlock family mysteries by looking through family records. Identify unknown individuals in photos by comparing them to other labeled photos or by taking them to a relative and seeing if they know.

• * Good: Add descriptions for each of the family history items you receive from others.
  • * Proficient: After adding the descriptions, make notes of missing information you want to investigate.

content.text:
1. Organize photos and documents you receive into your collection. Store physical copies in a safe place, and store digital files on your computer and in a backup location.
  2. In a separate document, add descriptions for each item (catalog them).
  3. Make notes of missing information and questions you have about any items.

resources.description: Here are some additional ideas on gathering memories.

links.text: LDS—Almost Buried Treasure - 1979

resources.description: Sources: Learn about other sources for finding family photographs.

links.text: AF—Unusual Sources for Finding Old Family Photos - 2017

resources.description: Photo Labels: Learn how to add labels to your photographs.

links.text: AC—4 Easy Ways to Label Family Photos - 2016

resources.description: Metadata: Learn how to add metadata (descriptions) to your digital photographs.

links.text: FS—Adding Metadata to Your Digital Photos
FS—Metadata Basics: How to Keep Your Stories Alive Digitally

name: Interview Others
section_name: Interview living relatives about their memories and life stories. Vault
summary: Capturing family history recollections from living relatives ensures that their legacy can be shared before they pass on.

choices.name: Prepare for successful interviews.

hidden.content:
• Label photos with as many details as you know (age, name, date it was taken, location, etc.).
  • When physically labelling the photo, use the correct type of writing utensil to preserve the photo as much as possible.
  • Journals, letters, and diaries are some of the most valuable family records, but photos and documents are just as useful.
  • You can often unlock family mysteries by looking through family records. Identify unknown individuals in photos by comparing them to other labelled photos or by taking them to a relative and seeing if they know.

• Before the interview
  • During the interview
  • After the interview

• * Good: Make a list of people who would be good candidates for interviews, and prepare a question to ask each of them.
  • * Proficient: Make the list and prepare a full set of questions for two interviews.

content.text:
1. People: Make a list of living people whose stories need to be captured. These people may also be good sources for photos and documents. This article discusses the benefits of interviewing living relatives.

    ☆ PR—The Benefits of Recording Your Living Family

  2. Questions: Prepare a list of questions in advance that will help each guest express family history experiences.

    ☆ Oral History Interviews, Topics, and Questions
    ☆ Step-by-Step Guide to Oral History

  3. Here are questions to ask your relatives in a family history interview.

    ☆ TH—50 Interview Questions to Ask

  4. Try these 52 questions for families, from FamilySearch.

    ☆ FS—52 Stories for Families
    ☆ FS—Define Your Dash: Start Writing Your Personal History with the #52Stories Project

  5. Ensure the questions are respectful and handle any delicate situations carefully.

    ☆ AR—Interviewing the Reluctant Relative

  6. Interview Tips: For tips on successfully capturing stories, read these articles.

    ☆ FS—Capture Grandma's Story
    ☆ LDS—That Happened to You?"

  7. Use these tips to help you conduct interviews with relatives.

    ☆ MH—Tips for Interviewing Family Members
    ☆ AC—Interviewing Family Members—28:13  
    • Before the interview
    • During the interview
    • After the interview

choices.name: Hold and record the interview.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Hold and record one interview.
  • * Proficient: Hold and record three or more interviews.

content.text:
1. App: To learn about using the FamilySearch Memories app to record stories, read these articles.

    ☆ FS—FamilySearch Memories App
    ☆ FS—Using FamilySearch Apps to Record Oral Histories

  2. Follow-up: Learn about reaching out to family members for genealogy information.

    ☆ FS—Learn from Family Members—4:14

  3. Learn about the two sides of interviewing, including steps to follow before, during, and after the interview.

    ☆ FS: The 2 Sides of Interviewing

choices.name: Upload the audio or written interview document to MyHeritage.

hidden.content: • * Proficient: Upload multiple interview items to MyHeritage.

content.text:
1. Decide which information should remain private (as in a family journal) and which can be uploaded to MyHeritage.
  2. Create descriptive notes for each interview document you created. These will be used in the upload process.
  3. Use the upload process described in Goal 5. If you have handwritten notes, digitize them first.

name: Prepare Uploads
section_name: Prepare photos and documents to be uploaded. Vault
summary: Getting the right photos that are in the right format will save you time and get better results.

choices.name: Scan any physical photos or documents that you want to upload, or take photos of documents with a digital device.

hidden.content:
• By posting photos, you agree to FamilySearch’s conditions.
  • Posting means you agree that you have the right to do so.
  • Photographs of living people should not be posted without prior consent.
  • Avoid posting photos that are duplicates or poor quality.

• * Good: Scan or take photos of the items you need to upload.
  • * Proficient: Same as above; also make a list of key learnings from the article or video in the Choice.

content.text:
1. Add descriptions for each item.(Scanning is preferable for quality; if you don't have a scanner or need help, you can visit a family history center for assistance.)
  2. Learn about creating and editing digital photos.

    ☆ TH—Creating and Editing Digital Photos - 2019

  3. Learn the basics of scanning for genealogists.

    ☆ BYU—Scanning Basics—63:00 - 2016




  4. Improve your digital photography skills.

    ☆ BYU—Digital Photography for Genealogists—57:39 - 2016


    ☆ Digital Photography for Genealogists—32:06

choices.name: (Optional) If necessary, crop or enhance photos or documents after scanning them.

content.text:
1. Use FreeOnlinePhotoEditor to enhance digital pictures in your browser.
  2. Try other resources for photo editing.
  3. Learn about colorizing photos in this article from MyHeritage.

    ☆ Colorize Your Black-and-White Photos Automatically - 2020.

name: Add Photos
section_name: Add and manage photos in your MyHeritage tree.
summary: Note : You can also upload videos, documents, and audio files, but videos and audio files cannnot be played on the site; they must first be downloaded from the site.

choices.name: Upload and view photos on your site.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Attach at least two photos for people in your tree and use the view options in this Choice.
  • * Proficient: Same as Good, for four or more photos.

content.text:
1. In the Photos menu, click My photos. The photos for your site are displayed on the screen.
  2. To upload an item to your tree,
    a) Click Upload;
    b) Drag the photo, video, or document onto the upload screen (or click Select files, navigate to the item, and click Open); and
    c) Click Done. For information on creating and viewing albums, see Goal 6).
  3. The following view options are available:
    • Click the plus or minus icon to zoom the photo view.
    • Click "View full size" to see the photo at its full size.
    • To get a larger viewing area, but not full size, click the right arrow (above "In the Photo" on the right side).
    • Click the left or right arrow (above the photo or next to the thumbnails in the upper right) to see the next or previous photo.
  4. To download an item to your computer, click the Download icon.

resources.description: Learn how to add a personal photo to someone in your tree.

links.text: MH—Add a Photo to Someone in My Tree

resources.description: This article explains the supported video and document formats.

links.text: MH—Upload Videos or Documents to My Family Site

choices.name: Edit or delete photos on your site.

content.text:
1. In My Photos, click the photo or video you want to edit.
  2. To edit the title of the item, hover over the title and click the pencil icon; then type the title you want and click Save. To add or edit the place where the photo was taken, use the link next to "Place". To add or edit the date of the photo, use the link next to "Date". The date options include data accuracy and day/month/year.
  3. To rotate the photo 90 degrees to the left, click the three-dot icon and select Rotate. You can select Rotate again for additional rotation.
  4. To see a link to the photo, click Show (right side).
  5. To digitally remove scratches from a photo, click the three-dot icon and select Repair. You can slide the "Before/After" bar to see the two versions of the photo.
  6. To add comments, type your comments in the field below the photo and click Add comment. The total number or comments for the photos is shown in the lower-right corner of the photo, when the album view is displayed.
  7. To share the photo with others, click Share and then select Share on Facebook or Share on Twitter and follow the steps. You can also click Copy link to clipboard so you can share via email or other social media.
  8. To delete a photo, click the three-dot icon, select "Original photo" or "Improved photo," and then click Yes in the confirmation dialog. This deletes the photo from the site and from all albums it appears in.

resources.description: This article explains how to replace the photo that appears in a person's card in the tree.

links.text: MH—Changing the Photo in a Person's Card

resources.description: Learn how to add a date to a photo on your site.

links.text: MH—Add a Date to a Photo

choices.name: Tag photos on your site to identify people.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Tag one or more people in at least two uploaded photos, changing the position for one of the tags.
  • * Proficient: Same as Good, for at least five uploaded photos.

content.text:
1. In the My Photos page, click the photo you want to tag.
  2. Click the "Who is this?" link next to the person's face and type the name of the person in your tree that matches the person in the photo. When you find the name in the drop-down list, select it.
  3. Click Done. The name of the person is added to the "In the photo" list.
  4. As an alternative, you can
    a) Click Tag person (right side);
    b) Drag and enlarge the photo frame around the person's face in the photo; and
    c) Type the name and select it from the list.
  5. To remove a tag, click the three-dot icon (right side) and select Remove tag.
  6. To tag someone else in the photo, click Tag another person and follow the steps above for tagging.
Photo Tagger
  1. To tag people across multiple photos, click Start in the Photo Tagger bar (top of the My photos page).
  2. Read the introduction page and check the consent box; then click Start. Photo Tagger goes through your uploaded photos to provide tagging suggestions.
  3. When Photo Tagger finishes the process, click Review.
  4. In the results screen, you can click "Identified people" or "Unidentified people" to filter the results.
  5. Click Review for any group of photos. Photos and tagging areas are displayed at the right of the screen. Make sure to review all the photos on the screen, scrolling down if necessary.
  6. To exclude tagging for a photo, uncheck the photo (right side); or click Reject (upper right) to exclude all the selected photos from tagging.
  7. To add a tag for all selected photos in the group, type an entry in the "Who is this?" box and select it from the list; then click the "Tag" button (upper right). The name tage is now applied to all the photos in the group.

Note : If MyHeritage detects that there are untagged faces in a photo, it may highlight them in rectangles. In that case, you can click the rectangle to name the person, or click the "Click to name" link under In the photo.

resources.description: Learn more about tagging people in your photos.

links.text: MH—Tag People in Photos

choices.name: Add or see details about people tagged in photos.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Add keywords and notes for at least two photos, and share one or more photos with someone else.
  • * Proficient: Same as Good, for at least five photos and two shares.

content.text:
1. To add keywords, which are used in searches for a photo or video,
    a) Click Add (next to Keywords);
    b) Type the keywords, separated by commas; and
    c) Click Apply.
  2. To add notes to a photo,
    a) Click Add (next to Notes);
    b) Type the notes; and
    c) Click Apply.
  3. To show the link (URL) for the current photo, click Show (next to Link to this photo). You can then copy and paste this link to share it with others. Click Hide to hide the link.
  4. Photo details are shown in the Info area, in the My Photos screen.
  5. To see a list of people who are tagged in your photos,
    a) In the My photos screen, click People (left side). You can then select an individual to see all photos or items that person is tagged in. To display items that have no tags, click "not Tagged" (bottom of the list).
  6. To search for media items that have a particular tag,
    a) Type the tag name into the Search field (upper right); and
    b) Click the magnifying glass to do the search. The search results screen has the following features:
    • Search fields (top)—To do another search, fill in the name field and click the blue arrow. (You can also choose to search for Albums instead of Photos.) To perform an advanced search, click "Show advanced search". You can use "AND" or "OR" keywords in the search field to control results. You can also select an item in the "Search in" drop-down to search only a certain type of source information.
    • All Photos—Shows all photos in the tree, not the search results
    • Thumbnail / List view—To switch to a thumbnail view for the search results, click the green thumbnail icon.
    • Sort by—Click the "Place", "Date", "Submitter", or "Last update" link to set the sort order for search results.
    • Per page—Click the "Per page" drop-down to select the number of results to display per page.
    • Information table—Shows details for each photo. Click a title or thumbnail to enlarge the photo. In Actions (right side) you can click View, Delete, or Album.

choices.name: Use the Instant Discoveries feature for photos.

content.text:
1. Learn more about photo discoveries in this article.

    ☆ MH—What Are Photo Discoveries?

  2. Learn how to add a photo discovery to your tree.

    ☆ MH—Add a Photo Discovery to My Tree

  3. This article explains how to reject a photo discovery.

    ☆ MH—Reject a Photo Discovery

name: Photo Albums
section_name: Use photo albums for your site.
summary: Online photo albums are a great way to organize and present your photos for ancestors in your tree.

choices.name: Create a photo album.

hidden.content: • * Proficient: Create a photo album and copy four or more photos to it.

content.text:
1. To add an album,
    a) In the Family tree menu, click My photos;
    b) Click Albums and then click the plus icon that appears;
    c) Add a title and description for the album;
    d) Select whether you want the album to be public or private; and
    e) Click Ok. The album title appears under "Albums" in the Media window.

    Note : Selecting photos in an album enables you to download them, add them to another album, or delete them.
  2. To select a photo, click its checkmark icon (upper-right corner of the photo). You can select multiple photos.
  3. To download selected photos, click the download icon (orange menu bar).
  4. To delete selected photos, click the three-dot icon (right edge of orange menu bar) and select Delete items.
  5. To copy selected photos to an album,
    a) Click the three-dot icon;
    b) Click Add to album;
    c) Select the album to receive the selected photo(s); and
    d) Click Add. You can also click Create in that dialog to add a new photo album.

  6. To unselect all photos you have selected, click Unselect.

choices.name: Manage your photo albums.

hidden.content:
• * Good: For an existing photo album, share it and edit information about it.
  • * Proficient: Same as Good; also, create a second photo album move one or more photos from one album to another.

content.text:
1. In the Albums list (left of the Family photos window), select a photo album title. The photos from the album are shown in the center of the window, with the title and a down-arrow just above.
  2. Next to the photo album title, click the down arrow to show photo album options.
  3. To share an album,
    a) Click Share album;
    b) Copy the album's URL (triple-click it and press Ctrl+C); and
    c) Paste the URL into an email or social media program to share the album with others.
  4. To download an album, click Download album.
  5. To edit information about the album,
    a) Click Album details;
    b) Change the title or description, or change the "Public album" setting; and
    c) Click Save.
  6. To delete an album,
    a) Click Delete album and then click Yes. The photos in the deleted album remain in your main Family photos album.

resources.description: This article explains how to move photos between albums in your tree.

links.text: MH—Move Photos between Albums on My Family Site

resources.description: This article explains how to download a photo album from your site.

links.text: MH—Download a Photo Album

resources.description: This article explains how to edit a photo album.

links.text: MH—Edit a Photo Album

resources.description: This article explains how to delete a photo from an online album.

links.text: MH—Delete a Photo from an Online Album

resources.description: This article explains how to delete a photo album.

links.text: MH—Delete a Photo Album

name: Use MyHeritage photo enhancements
section_name: Explore photo enhancement tools from MyHeritage.

choices.name: Use the Colorize Photos feature.

content.text:
1. In the Family tree menu click Colorize photos.
  2. Drag a photo into the colorizing frame on the right (or click Upload photo and navigate to your photo) and wait for the colorizing process to finish. The photo is displayed in half black-and-white, half color.
  3. To display all of the photo in color, click the color icon (upper right). To display all of the photo in black and white, click the black-and-white icon (upper right).
  4. To display part of the photo in color, move the arrow slider in the photo left or right.
  5. To share the photo with others, click Share on Facebook or Share on Twitter and follow the steps. You can also click Copy link to clipboard so you can share via email or other social media.
  6. To download the colorized photos to the Downloads area on your device, click Download photo (lower left) and then select Colorized photo or Comparison. The Comparison version includes the original photo at the top and the colorized version at the bottom.
  7. If you upload a color photo, the feature will restore original colors as much as possible. Follow the steps above for uploading a photo to be colorized.

    8. Note: Once you colorize or enhance a photo, the Colorize and Enhance buttons are deactivated in the window. To restore the buttons, delete the "improved" photo as explained in Choice B above.

Note: Once you colorize or enhance a photo, the Colorize and Enhance buttons are deactivated in the window. To restore the buttons, delete the "improved" photo as explained in Choice B above.

resources.description: Learn more about enhancing photos in these articles from MyHeritage.

links.text: MH—Colorize Your Black-and-White Photos Automatically
MH—Introducing Color Restoration on MyHeritage - 2021

choices.name: Use the Photo Enhancer feature.

content.text:
1. In the Family tree menu click Enhance photos.
  2. Drag a photo into the enhancement frame on the right (or click Upload photo and navigate to your photo) and wait for the enhancement process to finish. The enhanced photo is displayed in the screen. (As an alternative, you can open a person's photo in the My photos screen and click Enhance).
  3. To see different amounts of the enhacement, move the Before-After slider bar in the photo to the left or right.
  4. To see how the enhancement affects people's images in the photo, click any of the person thumbnails at the bottom.
  5. You can also click the Colorize photo button (top) to colorize the enhanced photo.
  6. To share the photo with others, click Share on Facebook or Share on Twitter and follow the steps. You can also click Copy link to clipboard so you can share via email or other social media.
  7. To download the enhanced photo to the Downloads area on your device, click Download photo (lower left) and then select Enhanced photo or Comparison. The Comparison version includes the original photo at the top and the enhanced version at the bottom.

resources.description: Learn more about enhancing photos in this article from MyHeritage.

links.text: MH—Introducing the MyHeritage Photo Enhancer - 2020

choices.name: Use the Deep Nostalgia feature.

content.text:
1. Go to the Deep Nostalgia page on MyHeritage.
  2. Click Upload Photo and navigate to the photo on your device that you want to animate; then click Open. (Your photo must be at least 300x300 pixels in size.) If necessary, the photo will be enhanced on the MyHeritage site before being animated. (As an alternative, you can open a person's photo in the Gallery and click Animate. If there are multiple people in the photo, you will be prompted to select one for animation.)
  3. To download the animation video, click Download video.
  4. To share the video on social media, click the Facebook or Twitter icon and follow the prompts. To copy the MyHeritage video link, click the Link icon.

resources.description: Learn more about Deep Notalgia in this article from MyHeritage.

links.text: MH—Deep Nostalgia™ is an Internet Sensation! - 2021

choices.name: Use the Deep Story feature.

content.text:
1. Go to the Deep Story page on MyHeritage.
  2. Select a photo from your gallery and click Create DeepStory.
  3. Click to accept the service terms, and then click Continue. A notification is sent to your email address when the DeepStory is ready. The story includes basic details about the person and the immediate family.
  4. To edit the story,
    a) Click Edit DeepStory;
    b) Edit the text for any chapter;
    c) Click a photo to chnge or remove it, or click a photo placeholder to add a new photo; and
    d) Click Save & Create.
  5. To download a finished story, click Download DeepStory.
  6. To see a list of all your DeepStory entries, click Go to my DeepStories.

resources.description: Learn more about DeepStory in this article from MyHeritage.

links.text: MH—Introducing DeepStory: Make Your Family Photos Speak - 2022
